@dhanasekar-arista FYI

> @dhanasekar-arista FYI

By logging these events at NOTICE level, we may miss some legitimate errors as well. While sonic-mgmt log analyzer may still see the NOTICE level entries and report them, this won't help customers who rely solely on monitoring the ERROR log level.

> > @dhanasekar-arista FYI
> 
> By logging these events at NOTICE level, we may miss some legitimate errors as well. While sonic-mgmt log analyzer may still see the NOTICE level entries and report them, this won't help customers who rely solely on monitoring the ERROR log level.

@kperumalbfn please share your opinion
@kperumalbfn , @developfast , please review

> > > @dhanasekar-arista FYI
> > 
> > 
> > By logging these events at NOTICE level, we may miss some legitimate errors as well. While sonic-mgmt log analyzer may still see the NOTICE level entries and report them, this won't help customers who rely solely on monitoring the ERROR log level.
> 
> @kperumalbfn please share your opinion

NOTICE is still be part of sonic syslog as the default log level is NOTICE for swss.

> > > > @dhanasekar-arista FYI
> > > 
> > > 
> > > By logging these events at NOTICE level, we may miss some legitimate errors as well. While sonic-mgmt log analyzer may still see the NOTICE level entries and report them, this won't help customers who rely solely on monitoring the ERROR log level.
> > 
> > 
> > @kperumalbfn please share your opinion
> 
> NOTICE is still be part of sonic syslog as the default log level is NOTICE for swss.

Yes, but customer syslog monitoring tool may have different alarms raised for different levels. And there is a chance that a valid error log may be missed. Hence i'm not in favor of this change.

Hi @judyjoseph @wumiaont @senthil-nexthop ,  `sonic_fips=1` is always set in /proc/cmdline in master. Is this expected? With this setting,  this PR will always enable POST in SAI switch creation, which fails. As a result, MACSec is not working.

Based on the GitHub checks, the "changes can be cleanly merged" without having to rebase.

> Hi @judyjoseph @wumiaont @senthil-nexthop , `sonic_fips=1` is always set in /proc/cmdline in master. Is this expected? With this setting, this PR will always enable POST in SAI switch creation, which fails. As a result, MACSec is not working.

My understanding is that the command "sonic-installer set-fips" will set sonic_fips=1 in kernel command line. Are you saying this is always set in the image during build? Is this a recent change?

> > Hi @judyjoseph @wumiaont @senthil-nexthop , `sonic_fips=1` is always set in /proc/cmdline in master. Is this expected? With this setting, this PR will always enable POST in SAI switch creation, which fails. As a result, MACSec is not working.

> My understanding is that the command "sonic-installer set-fips" will set sonic_fips=1 in kernel command line. Are you saying this is always set in the image during build? Is this a recent change?

Hi @senthil-nexthop , I noticed this with our latest internal image built with upstream master changes. I am not aware of any internal patch to enable FIPS. So this setting is likely from upstream.

> > > Hi @judyjoseph @wumiaont @senthil-nexthop , `sonic_fips=1` is always set in /proc/cmdline in master. Is this expected? With this setting, this PR will always enable POST in SAI switch creation, which fails. As a result, MACSec is not working.
> >

> > My understanding is that the command "sonic-installer set-fips" will set sonic_fips=1 in kernel command line. Are you saying this is always set in the image during build? Is this a recent change?
> 
> Hi @senthil-nexthop , I noticed this with our latest internal image built with upstream master changes. I am not aware of any internal patch to enable FIPS. So this setting is likely from upstream.

Hi @judyjoseph @wumiaont @senthil-nexthop ,  we checked internally and found that we do have internal patch that may enable FIPS in our SONiC build. This is probably the reason that we observed `sonic_fips=1` in /proc/cmdline in our internally built image. Sorry for the false alarm.  

Based on today's discussion,  we are going to revise the PR to follow what @rlhui suggested. That's Orchagent sets POST result based on SAI capabilities, but not global FIPS config (e.g., `sonic_fips` in /proc/cmdline). So in the same scenario here (FIPS is enabled but SAI does not support POST), Orchagent will set POST result to `disabled` (MACSec is not disabled),  instead of `failed`.  Orchagent sets POST result to `failed` only when SAI POST is supported and fails.

Hi @judyjoseph One more clarification here. With the latest change in the PR,  Orchagent does not declare SAI POST to fail if SAI does not support POST. In this case, MACSec is still enabled. This allows to use MACSec with existing SAI, e.g., 13.x, that does not support SAI POST. In other words, the change is the PR is just no-op with existing SAI.

@vaibhavhd @Ryangwaite Issues happens after https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-swss/pull/3563 as pointed by author.

After seperating this change from larger PR I missed the right order, in the original PR the m_oper_status usage is correct, after it is initialized - https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-swss/pull/3529/files#diff-bb736c6a11da68afacf95d761fb52a3c11726cdd72c967d4803b8c9b1a6dcb69R6241. 

Unfortunatelly, there's no coverage for SAI_HOSTIF_ATTR_OPER_STATUS (it's ignored) on Nvidia as driver manages oper status of the netdev. 
So, I added a UT to make sure it won't happen again.
Change looks good. I will verify that it fixes the issue on Broadcom before approving

    def test_PortMirrorQueue(self, dvs, testlog):
        """
        This test covers valid and invalid values of the queue parameter.  All sessions have source & dest port.
        Operation flow:
        1. Create mirror session with queue 0, verify session becomes active and error not written to log.
        2. Create mirror session with queue max valid value, verify session becomes active and error not written to log.
        3. Create mirror session with queue max valid value + 1, verify session doesnt get created and error written to log.
        Due to lag in table operations, verify_no_mirror is necessary at the end of each step, to ensure cleanup before next step.
        Note that since orchagent caches max valid value during initialization, this test cannot simulate a value from SAI, e.g.
        by calling setReadOnlyAttr, because orchagent has already completed initialization and would never read the simulated value.
        Therefore, the default value must be used, MIRROR_SESSION_DEFAULT_NUM_TC which is defined in mirrororch.cpp as 255.
        """
    
        session = "TEST_SESSION"
        dst_port = "Ethernet16"
        src_ports = "Ethernet12"
    
        # Sub Test 1
        marker = dvs.add_log_marker()
        self.dvs_mirror.create_span_session(session, dst_port, src_ports, direction="BOTH", queue="0")
        self.dvs_mirror.verify_session_status(session)
        self.dvs_mirror.remove_mirror_session(session)
        self.dvs_mirror.verify_no_mirror()
        self.check_syslog(dvs, marker, "Failed to get valid queue 0", 0)
    
        # Sub Test 2
        marker = dvs.add_log_marker()
        self.dvs_mirror.create_span_session(session, dst_port, src_ports, direction="RX", queue="15")
        self.dvs_mirror.verify_session_status(session)
        self.dvs_mirror.remove_mirror_session(session)
        self.dvs_mirror.verify_no_mirror()
        self.check_syslog(dvs, marker, "Failed to get valid queue 15", 0)
    
        # Sub Test 3
        marker = dvs.add_log_marker()
        self.dvs_mirror.create_span_session(session, dst_port, src_ports, direction="TX", queue="16")
        self.dvs_mirror.verify_session_status(session, expected=0)
        self.dvs_mirror.remove_mirror_session(session)
        self.dvs_mirror.verify_no_mirror()

@prsunny there is one line change with a single commit. The concerns are not clear to me.

The standard strategy of updating the feature branches is doing a rebase on top of parent, which saves the commit history and puts them on the same row. This makes the history as clean as possible. AFAIK, after the feature branch is merged to upstream the made commits are being squashed, so it actually neglects all the work done on top of that branch. So after the feature branch is merged you still get a single commit.

Do u agree with that? Am i missing something?

Please link the following HLD PR in description https://github.com/sonic-net/SONiC/pull/1961

@prsunny, @bingwang-ms I see that current aclorch doesn't allow dynamic addition/removal of a counter on an ACL rule(its more of a create time attribute directly put into the code and not configurable via a config db field value), I wonder if it might help to introduce a new field value called enable_counter to ACL_RULE, which aclorch consumes and we may enable/disable it on demand for issue investigations using config_db. Reason why its needed: for this use-case the ACL_RULE scale+ number of matched packets will be very high, hence we cannot have a per rule counter enabled by default, hence if counters are ever needed it would need to be an on-demand thing and turned on for some particular ACL_RULE only. If we choose to not have counters then packet capture would be the alternative way to investigate problems.

> @prsunny, @bingwang-ms I see that current aclorch doesn't allow dynamic addition/removal of a counter on an ACL rule(its more of a create time attribute directly put into the code and not configurable via a config db field value), I wonder if it might help to introduce a new field value called enable_counter to ACL_RULE, which aclorch consumes and we may enable/disable it on demand for issue investigations using config_db. Reason why its needed: for this use-case the ACL_RULE scale+ number of matched packets will be very high, hence we cannot have a per rule counter enabled by default, hence if counters are ever needed it would need to be an on-demand thing and turned on for some particular ACL_RULE only. If we choose to not have counters then packet capture would be the alternative way to investigate problems.

@anish-n , agree to your point that we should have a flexibility but this would need some good amount of changes and need to ensure default behavior is not changed. For this usecase, could you also share in description, the scale of ACL rules we are looking at? For the most part, it is possible that ASICs have that many counters.

> > @prsunny, @bingwang-ms I see that current aclorch doesn't allow dynamic addition/removal of a counter on an ACL rule(its more of a create time attribute directly put into the code and not configurable via a config db field value), I wonder if it might help to introduce a new field value called enable_counter to ACL_RULE, which aclorch consumes and we may enable/disable it on demand for issue investigations using config_db. Reason why its needed: for this use-case the ACL_RULE scale+ number of matched packets will be very high, hence we cannot have a per rule counter enabled by default, hence if counters are ever needed it would need to be an on-demand thing and turned on for some particular ACL_RULE only. If we choose to not have counters then packet capture would be the alternative way to investigate problems.
> 
> @anish-n , agree to your point that we should have a flexibility but this would need some good amount of changes and need to ensure default behavior is not changed. For this usecase, could you also share in description, the scale of ACL rules we are looking at? For the most part, it is possible that ASICs have that many counters.

Makes sense, and agree that it will be some amount of change and requires code+validation for backwards compatibility. The scale is 10k ACL rules(included in the HLD as well), will check on whether the ASIC side can support it easily. @kavyavanibedida could you please help add 10k as rule scale to the PR description as suggested?

@balanokia This PRs addresses an issue where SAI_PORT_ATTR_FEC_MODE is configured twice - when creating a port and then configured again in doPortTask. However, since gearbox port is not available at create the FEC attribute needs to be set at some point. This `else` block that you mentioned is exactly the same as in the code for speed handling. So, basically I applied the same approach as for speed.

Hi, @stepanblyschak. There are 2 types of ports in the system - ASIC hosting and PHY hosting. ASIC MAC port index is at the hierarchically higher level and it needs to be indexed by all SONiC operations. setPortFec would cascase the necessary changes from ASIC to the the PHY hosting. PHY/PAI has a host of configuration and it needs to be computed using gearbox configuration. Its the same design for Speed as well. Its not compliant with the current Gearbox design. Its not clear how you tested using any physical PHY devices. I would be creating an issue to delete the code that calls directly gearbox attributes modification during SET operation.  Thanks.

@balanokia I understand your concern. I do not have any devices to test with PHY ports and rely on UT/VS for this part. I am ok with you removing this block for fec that I added and for speed that was already there as it does not do anything on my platform.

> @stepanblyschak this change does not look to be relevant to port initialization speed up. can we take this separately?

@prgeor It is related. We have two flows of port initialization -

- SAI starts with default ports and we get MTU in getPortMtu() which calls SAI get API.
- We create ports not providing MTU value. In this case the MTU should be default as defined by SAI headers. So I avoid getting it from SAI.

This define is used to initialize m_mtu variable. Since getPortMtu() always substracts MAX_MACSEC_SECTAG_SIZE I updated this define to match the value that would have been returned by getPortMtu().

This [coverage.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/18609193/coverage.zip) contains the coverage.info and _buggy_ coverage.xml obtained from artifacts of [PR#3242](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-swss/pull/3242), _**without**_ the change of this PR#3482.
@saiarcot895 @theasianpianist @prsunny 

you can check by searching `SF:/__w/1/s/orchagent/orch.cpp` in the attached `coverage.info` and would find 4 copies there, to be more specific, you can search `FN:36,_ZN10RingBuffer6notifyEv` in `coverage.info`, which is a function defined in orch.cpp, and would see 4 copies of `FNDA` there, which are 0, 0, 3, 0. It means this function is hit by 0, 0, 3, 0 times, hence a total of 0+0+3+0=3 times.

But in `coverage.xml`, this function is counted as hit by 0 times, because it only check the last `FNDA` in `coverage.info`.

What this #PR3482 wants to fix is that, use --add-trace-file option for lcov, so that it could sum up all `FNDA`  to get the correct hit times for a function. Otherwise, some covered functions would be considered as missing, by mistake.

The best fix for this is to rework the automake build files to not need to compile the same files repeatedly. This probably involves switching to non-recursive automake, and takes a bit of time to do so without breaking anything. This is a good enough short-term fix, at least.

commit 5d415c1385697887a02d844e82164d97c0517bdb (HEAD)
Author: Stephen Sun <5379172+stephenxs@users.noreply.github.com>

    Avoid removing a VRF routing table when there are pending creation entries in gRouteBulker (#3477)
    
    * Set bytes to 0 before copying IPv4 addresses/masks to avoid uninitialized bytes
    * Avoid removing a VRF routing table when there are pending creation entries in gRouteBulker
    
    Remove a VRF routing table when a routing entry is removed only if there is no pending creation entry in gRouteBulker
    Avoid uninitialized value SAI IP address/prefix structure
    Why I did it

commit f74afca96110725075f7f72a3973bea64570b0c2
Author: abdosi <58047199+abdosi@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Wed Dec 18 23:09:21 2024 +0530

    Added change not to create ECMP Group in SAI and program the route if none of ECMP members are active/link-up (#3394)
    
    What I did:
    Added change not to create ECMP Group in SAI and program the route if none of the ECMP members are active/link-up.
    Also do not program the Temp Route if Neigh is not active (Link Down)
    
    Also as part of this change if Route is not programmed and if we remove that route than decrement VRF Reference count in removeRoute as removeRoutePost will not be called in this case.
    
    Why I did:
    In scale setup of T2 it's possible all links can go down simultaneously which case we can get Route messages with all nexthops being in down state. In such case we might create empty Nexthop Group in SAI for the given route which causes not needed SAI call for Nexthop Group creation and also create traffic blackhole for the route where that route can still forward traffic via default route if eligible/applicable.
    
    Also in this case no point to add Temp Route if neighbor is link down.

People using things like Ansible, don't use the CLI to set configuration.  They modify the `/etc/sonic/config_db.json` which does nothing to prevent this. @prsunny
> Agree with @dgsudharsan , this is checked in the CLI and Yang level. I dont think its really needed in swss.

Your evaluation is not correct.

First, its not occurring at the yang level as per:

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/blob/d28b734ce545762cd7b49d110575eec8549458cf/src/sonic-yang-models/yang-models/sonic-port.yang#L162-L166

There are no restrictions on MTU being set for a port.

But that's besides the point.  My configuration that triggered this behavior, as can be seen in the PR summary, did not have an MTU set at all on the port:
```
{
    "PORT": {
        "Ethernet0": {
            "admin_status": "up",
            "alias": "twentyfiveGigE1/1/1",
            "autoneg": "off",
            "description": "PortChannel1 mgmt",
            "fec": "rs",
            "index": "1",
            "lanes": "49",
            "speed": "25000"
        },
       ...
}
```

That means its getting inherited somewhere (I didn't look where), triggering it to call `/sbin/ip link set dev "Ethernet0" mtu "9100"`

Ok, found where its being set by default to 9100, a hardcoded code path:

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-swss/blob/c20902f3195b5bf8a941045e131aa1b863b69fd0/cfgmgr/portmgr.cpp#L163-L172

Which is right above:

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-swss/blob/c20902f3195b5bf8a941045e131aa1b863b69fd0/cfgmgr/portmgr.cpp#L222-L226

Which is where it crashes due to the exception caused by `setPortMtu()`.

The macro for the default value is here:

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-swss/blob/c20902f3195b5bf8a941045e131aa1b863b69fd0/cfgmgr/portmgr.h#L15

There's no way that any CLI or Yang verification can prevent a hardcoded default in the code path.

Well, I can 100% confirm without this patch, trying to bring up a portchannel interface with the config in the summary on a Dell S5248F (Broadcom Trident 3) fails due to the aforementioned error of:
```
2024 Dec 17 19:26:20.964259 sw1 INFO swss#supervisord: portmgrd RTNETLINK answers: Operation not permitted
2024 Dec 17 19:26:20.965353 sw1 ERR swss#portmgrd: :- main: Runtime error: /sbin/ip link set dev "Ethernet0" mtu "9100" : 
2024 Dec 17 19:26:20.967020 sw1 INFO swss#supervisord 2024-12-17 19:26:20,966 WARN exited: portmgrd (exit status 255; not expected)
```

Once portmgrd exits, its all over, the switch is down on both 202411 and master.  This is observed on a fresh boot with the configuration, I did observe that if adding the ports to a portchannel with a switch already running the error does not occur, presumable some order of operations aspect of bringing up a portchannel at boot vs configuring it at runtime.

I haven't tried portchannel on any other releases.  Since you aren't aware of any issue, I'm assuming this is a recent issue with the 'ip link' command returning failure these days where as previously maybe it did not return a failure and simply was a no-op ... or maybe there was a change the order in the way portchannels vs ports are brought up during boot. I can't say.

Either way this PR corrects the issue.

I'm not sure I understand what you are saying.

The issue has nothing to do with config_db.json at all, it is a regression affecting all portchannels brought up during boot (at least on real hardware as of Oct 2024 due to 8b99543).  This is reproduced with *no* mtu specified at all in the config_db.json, because a default of `9100` is set in the c++ code of portmgr, this is not a value read from the config at all.  

This is not observed in the current upstream code after the initial port bring-up, such as if adding a portchannel after boot because the code to set the default mtu is NOT called in that case.  So yes, you have to reboot the switch with your saved configuration having a portchannel configured to observe the issue, but that is the only way in which it relates to config_db.json.

If you look at the minimal changeset in doTask(), I tried to make the change as comprehensible as possible there.  The main fix there is to unset the MTU specified earlier ONLY IF it was ***not*** specified in the port configuration *and* it is a LAG Member.

@stepanblyschak 
> @bradh352 As I understand it, you enounter a crash that reveals design issues of kernel configuration of ports/lags - port and lag kernel configuration are inherently dependent but portmgrd and teammgrd are running completelly unaware of each other. The `mtu` field of the port becomes meaningless when port is enslaved as it inherits lag mtu, but is used later in teammgrd when removing a lag member to restore port mtu to its original value. Given solution to check lag member configuration is still prone to data races post boot. On the other hand, you seem to be more concerned about the crash behaviour, how about not crash when `ip` command fails, instead, report an error in syslog? A correct mtu value will be restored by teammgrd if user removes lag member configuration.

First, there is no race condition here post-boot.  The default MTU value is only set if the port didn't previously exist in the PORT table, so that's a boot-time thing, not a post-boot thing.  That said, I could see during a quick review where that's not obvious due to the github default context it outputs when viewing the diff, you need to expand and you'll see the MTU is only set in the `if (!configured)` codepath.

This patch also includes the logic you suggest, where it won't cause portmgrd to exit if that command fails (which at this point is only if the user explicitly configured an MTU on a port belonging to a port channel which they should not be doing).

I'm a big advocate that logs should not contain warnings or errors that users should NOT be looking at.  Anything that could cause confusion while debugging a real issue should not be introduced.  So simply doing your suggestion is quite honestly not acceptable.

> @stepanblyschak
> 
> > @bradh352 As I understand it, you enounter a crash that reveals design issues of kernel configuration of ports/lags - port and lag kernel configuration are inherently dependent but portmgrd and teammgrd are running completelly unaware of each other. The `mtu` field of the port becomes meaningless when port is enslaved as it inherits lag mtu, but is used later in teammgrd when removing a lag member to restore port mtu to its original value. Given solution to check lag member configuration is still prone to data races post boot. On the other hand, you seem to be more concerned about the crash behaviour, how about not crash when `ip` command fails, instead, report an error in syslog? A correct mtu value will be restored by teammgrd if user removes lag member configuration.
> 
> First, there is no race condition here post-boot. The default MTU value is only set if the port didn't previously exist in the PORT table, so that's a boot-time thing, not a post-boot thing. That said, I could see during a quick review where that's not obvious due to the github default context it outputs when viewing the diff, you need to expand and you'll see the MTU is only set in the `if (!configured)` codepath.
> 
> This patch also includes the logic you suggest, where it won't cause portmgrd to exit if that command fails (which at this point is only if the user explicitly configured an MTU on a port belonging to a port channel which they should not be doing).
> 
> I'm a big advocate that logs should not contain warnings or errors that users should NOT be looking at. Anything that could cause confusion while debugging a real issue should not be introduced. So simply doing your suggestion is quite honestly not acceptable.

Ports can be added at runtime in case of port breakout/split.

Post boot race I can think of is:
1. User writes to ```PORT``` table a new port
2. ```portmgrd``` reads ```LAG_MEMBER``` table and ```isLagMember``` returns false.
3. User writes to ```LAG_MEMBER``` table
4. ```teammgrd``` enslaves port in a lag
5.  ```portmgrd``` executes ```ip link set mtu``` and crash

And by the user here I mean a CLI or a script that does the update non atomically and fast enough to trigger a race.

Regarding a case when mtu is set by the user - I do not fully understand what the user should do if port is already configured with mtu and he wants to add port to a LAG? There's no such thing as "unset" mtu. You can enforce mtu on a port to match mtu on a LAG in CLI but you can't block user from adding a port to a lag if it has mtu configured nor crash in that case either.

I fully agree with your opinion about the log. My point is a bit more general - there's no reason for ```portmgrd``` to crash when ```ip``` command fails. A failure to set port mtu or admin state in the kernel does not invalidate ```portmgrd```'s state and so I think the daemon just needs to continue being operational and handle configs for other ports.

So, I mean there are actually two different issues:
1. ```portmgrd``` takes down the whole system (when autorestart is enabled) when failing to execute ```ip``` command
2. ```portmgrd``` assigns mtu on lag members when it makes no sense to do so

Does solving # 1 unblocks you from deploying your systems?

SIGTERM signal to the teamd supervisord was sent at 07:41:40, and the container exited at 07:41:46.

Teamd container is also configured to have a 60-second wait time (instead of the 10-second wait time) for termination, meaning docker will wait 60 seconds for the container to go down before forcefully killing it. This means that a 6-second wait time here is fine.
